Chemotherapy continued, and we all hoped that perhaps these were benign formations arising as a side effect of therapy that had pushed her immune system to the limit. No surgeries were performed. They decided to postpone removal of the tumors. The main thing was to complete all planned chemo cycles.

    Susannah held on. Quietly, patiently, almost invisibly—as if trying not to be a burden to anyone.

chapters.title: 36. HALF A YEAR WITHOUT IMMUNITY
chapters.html:
In May 2024 I sold the rental apartment—this allowed me to close the worst financial debts and loans. Free funds appeared, and from that moment I could again provide Adam with meaningful financial support.

    Then, also in May, Adam contacted the oncologist. Over the time that had passed, emotions had cooled a bit. The oncologist was no longer so indignant and listened to Adam, acknowledging that many previous decisions and actions had been taken without his direct participation and didn’t reflect his own wishes or choices. He also stressed that he didn’t take it as a slight to his help and recognized the sincerity of Adam’s intentions.

    As a result, the oncologist decided to resume support and organize a course of treatment that for Adam would be essentially free, with only related expenses to be covered. All of this was planned for June. By then Adam still had time to restore his blood counts and bone marrow function. Recall: since December 2023—half a year—his immune system had been practically absent, his white cell level close to zero.

chapters.title: 37. JUNE: GOOD NEWS
chapters.html:
In June 2024 Adam went to a California clinic where experimental CAR‑T and immunotherapy studies—the ones he had been receiving—were being conducted. Everything was going very well. Adam also underwent rehabilitation procedures, and his mobility returned literally within a few days. Bone marrow and blood tests showed that no traces of leukemia were detected, and his immune system was functioning almost in a normal mode.

    This news inspired not only Adam but also the team of physicians involved in the studies. In fact, the numbers were so good that we decided: Adam was cured.

    About half a year had passed since he had received the immunotherapy cells, and there were no signs of disease.

    Adam spent two weeks at Stanford, after which he returned to the apartment in New York. His mood improved noticeably; he became more active and began making plans for the future.

    During this period he took one important legal action: despite the freeze on access to his assets, he still had the right to manage his housing. Adam officially prohibited his sister from living in the apartment, and she was forced to leave it. The apartment was shuttered, although unfortunately it was cleared of property because further storage required substantial monthly expenses.

chapters.title: 38. A COURT WITH NO DEADLINES
chapters.html:
While Adam gathered documents for the court hearing, he was simultaneously actively recovering—doing exercises, gradually increasing the load, going out for walks, regaining strength and confidence.

    In July he prepared for the hearing, collecting all documentation on his personal assets, bank accounts, and earnings—everything unrelated to his parents’ inheritance.

    At that moment Roxana brought him a large suitcase of papers that allowed him to present his position in court more fully.

    Thus, three years after the freeze of his property, a preliminary court hearing finally took place.

    However, the judge noted that the process was extremely complex and convoluted, involving inherited assets in different countries, and that given Adam was neither a resident nor a citizen of the U.S., the case could drag on for years.

    Even so, Adam submitted all required documents, counting on a prompt decision.

    At the same time, given his success in treatment, unfreezing the property wasn’t his top priority then, and his parents’ inheritance didn’t particularly concern him—he didn’t seek it and didn’t care about its fate.

    He began making plans to work and earn to cover daily expenses and build his own funds.

    We also planned an in-person meeting.

    Everything was going well, but by the end of July events began to occur that once again brought drama into our story called The Real Unreal Story.

chapters.title: 39. MELISSA’S PALM
chapters.html:
On one July evening in 2024, an incident occurred that could have become a true tragedy. It involved Adam’s brother—the one who had suffered a severe traumatic brain injury and moved with difficulty. Recall: in April he was undergoing rehab, and it had worked—he had become more mobile.

    Late at night Melissa—the caregiver tending to the brother—noticed he had gotten out of bed and was slowly heading for Adam’s room. Something about his movements alerted Melissa, and without saying a word she followed. As she drew near, she was gripped by a cold horror: a kitchen knife glinted in the brother’s hand.

    Without thinking, Melissa dashed forward. The brother was already entering Adam’s room. Adam slept deeply and suspected nothing. Everything happened in seconds.

    The brother approached the bed and began stabbing—aiming at the abdomen. But at that very instant Melissa managed to put her hand in the way. One of the blows landed squarely in her palm. The knife pierced skin and soft tissue, but only barely grazed Adam’s body. Melissa screamed in pain and fear. Hearing her and seeing the blood, the brother suddenly froze. He started repeating that he didn’t understand anything, that it wasn’t him. In a panic, as if waking from a nightmare, he suddenly turned the knife on himself and slit his veins. It all happened so quickly and chaotically that it was hard to tell where reality ended and madness began.

    There was blood in the room—on the floor, on the bed, on Melissa’s hands.

    Melissa called an ambulance. All three—Adam, Melissa, and Adam’s brother—were taken to the hospital. The medics provided necessary care: Melissa’s wound was treated and stitched, Adam was examined and kept for brief observation, and the brother underwent urgent intervention and was hospitalized for further observation and psychiatric evaluation.

    The next morning Adam and Melissa returned to the apartment. Both were physically drained, but alive.

    The brother remained in the hospital. The medical opinion later confirmed: the episode occurred against the background of parasomnia—the so-called “sleep with motor acts,” caused by organic brain damage. In other words, Adam’s brother had a sleepwalking attack during which he lost control of himself.

    It is worth noting that relations between Melissa and the brother had always been tense. She tried to perform her duties professionally, but he often showed aggression and distrust. After that night she made a final decision—she resigned voluntarily and asked to be transferred to another assignment.

    The brother returned to the apartment a few days later. He said he was ashamed, that he remembered nothing. He spent several days away from home, avoiding contact. We never learned where he had been all that time. Perhaps he was trying to grasp what had happened. Perhaps he simply didn’t want to look into the eyes of the brother whose life he had almost taken. I am inclined to believe he truly didn’t realize what he was doing that night. His damaged brain could have played a sinister trick. But that doesn’t make it easier.

    It was yet another turn in a story where pain and rescue again teetered on the edge.

chapters.title: 40. “WHY ARE YOU HOLDING ME?”
chapters.html:
But the incident with sleepwalking and the brother’s injury turned out to be only part of the shocks of that period.

    Precisely because of that trauma, Adam was given a CT and ultrasound of the abdominal cavity. The routine checkup became a revelation: large tumorous foci were found in the abdomen.

    Adam told no one. Neither me nor Roxana. Only Melissa knew—and that by chance: she was there during the hospitalization.

    Immediately after that, Adam changed again. He became distant, sometimes irritable. As if he carried something heavy inside and didn’t want to discuss it with anyone. I didn’t understand what was happening then. Adam asked strange questions—why I was helping him, what I saw in him, why I was trying to hold him in this life. He spoke sharply, as if accusing. It seemed absurd and hurtful. I didn’t know he was simply desperately trying to understand why to go on.

    The answer came a few hours later. Melissa suddenly wrote me—from his phone. She had found Adam unconscious in the bathroom. He had fainted, fallen, and hit his head.

    Later it became clear: his hemoglobin was critically low—around 8. Then Melissa told me everything: about the tumors, his ban on speaking about it, his fear.

    She added that Adam had tried to find at least some job—say, in a small shop near the house where she often bought groceries. He had arranged the job in advance, even before he knew about the tumor. After the incidental discovery of the abdominal foci, Adam decided he could pay for diagnostics with the money he earned.

    Melissa helped: she passed money through the shop owners as if it were his wages. Into his hands—he wouldn’t have taken it.

    Later, under the oncologist’s supervision, Adam took tests. The diagnosis was serious: an aggressive form of Hodgkin lymphoma. Not at all what he had been fighting before. It wasn’t a continuation of leukemia. It was a new war, a new disease.

    In all likelihood, the lymphoma developed as a side effect of CAR‑T therapy against the background of total immune depletion. Hodgkin lymphoma is a fairly typical malignant fellow traveler of such procedures.

    I told Roxana the shocking news. It turned out she already knew—from the oncologist.

    We discussed it together. The oncologist proposed heavy but potentially effective chemotherapy. It was a chance.

    I was stunned. Literally a month earlier the tests had been clean. We believed he was cured. But everything began again—on a new battlefield.

chapters.title: 41. SKEPTICISM AND CONSENT
chapters.html:
Learning that new chemotherapy was needed, Adam naturally met it with deep skepticism. He thought it pointless—so much had already been tried, and even after such individualized, complex treatment as CAR‑T, returning to chemotherapy again seemed hopeless to him. But I didn’t want to give up.

    Roxana also wanted to help, despite being morally exhausted—especially considering the parallel, heavy ordeal with Susannah in her country.

    We devised a plan. We decided how the process would be organized to support Adam.

    The oncologist managed to arrange for the chemotherapy to take place in California, where Adam could temporarily live free of charge and receive the necessary supervision and care. However, to conduct the chemotherapy itself required meeting strict conditions. In particular, for three days during each cycle Adam had to stay at the medical hotel attached to the clinic—this was a mandatory requirement. Each day of lodging cost about $400, so three days came to roughly $1,200. In addition, expensive medications were needed to combat side effects. Roxana and I took on organizing the entire process: I was ready to help financially, Roxana—to handle logistics and care, including ordering food via delivery services. It was only a plan—a working, realistic plan, but still a plan.

    I had to spend quite a while persuading Adam to agree to this new treatment. Despite his refusals and fears, I did manage to convince him to try.

    The oncologist warned right away that the chemotherapy would be heavy, complicated, and demand serious endurance. But there seemed to be no other way.

    Thus, at the end of August 2024, Adam headed to California again. So began a new stage of the fight—not only for him, but also for Roxana and me.

    I’ll note separately that the tickets to California were bought by Melissa—this kind, sincere gesture stayed with me for a long time.

chapters.title: 42. A LOAN FOR LIFE
chapters.html:
In California Adam received the first dose of chemotherapy.

    Soon after that a very severe itch began—so tormenting it was impossible to bear. He could neither sleep nor lie still nor remain in a familiar space. The itch exhausted him, and although he knew he must not scratch, in the end he couldn’t stand it and began to claw at himself, damaging the skin. That became the critical moment: a few days after the itching started, his temperature rose—to almost 40°F (104°F). The oncologist immediately understood: a serious infection had developed, caused by skin injuries that had become gateways for bacteria. The situation was so dangerous that action had to be taken literally within minutes.

    The oncologist reacted quickly—he arranged transportation to a hospital where he had a strong reputation and had negotiated a substantial discount for diagnostics and treatment. Despite the discount, the costs remained very high—more than ten thousand dollars—and I had to take out a loan again, because there were no free funds. But there was no choice—we had to keep fighting.

    In the hospital, after thorough diagnostics, they confirmed severe sepsis with a high concentration of bacteria in the blood. Infection markers showed up almost immediately, although such tests sometimes take days. Thanks to promptly selected antibiotics, the dangerous process was contained.

    The oncologist, despite the difficulties, insisted on continuing treatment and proposed changing the chemotherapy regimen—making it gentler so as not to provoke repeated complications.

    After recovering from the infection, Adam was switched to a new, mild therapy. The first dose passed with almost no side effects: he could eat and drink normally, there was no vomiting. Subsequent sessions were tougher—vomiting and other reactions appeared, but they lasted relatively briefly: beginning on the third day and easing by the fifth or sixth. Overall the treatment was going quite successfully, which was signaled by the oncologist’s calm, approving silence.

    However, during that period a serious incident occurred: Adam fell and badly smashed his nose—so much so that the bones could not heal on their own. After consultations they decided on rhinoplasty. The operation was expensive—$12,000—but I assumed the full payment to ensure proper recovery and relieve his condition.

chapters.title: 43. ALARM AND A TURNAROUND
chapters.html:
In December 2024, after the sixth dose of chemotherapy, Adam wrote that he and the oncologist were going to meet another doctor. He gave no details—only noted that the meeting should clarify several questions. Later he explained: the other doctor studied the tests, discussed everything at length with the oncologist, and Adam himself hardly participated—he waited outside the door. The minutes dragged endlessly.

    In the end only a feeling of uncertainty and anxiety remained. The atmosphere was heavy, with palpable wariness and lack of understanding. No one could say exactly what was happening or what to expect next.

    Adam noted that after the meeting the oncologist changed: he became noticeably more attentive and more anxious. It was the beginning of a new stage—the doctor seemed to be reassessing the situation and preparing for hard decisions.

    The time came for the next dose of chemotherapy. Adam immediately saw: the solution in the IV looked different—meaning the treatment scheme was new. This chemo proved distinctly heavier than the previous one: side effects appeared more vividly and harshly.

    After the procedure the oncologist told Roxana something important: within two weeks the white blood cell count had risen to an abnormal figure—about 200,000. That was an alarming signal: Hodgkin lymphoma had developed resistance; the tumor had stopped responding to therapy.

    Together with the other specialist, the oncologist examined the situation closely and decided: the protocol had to be changed. He arranged with the clinic to replace the regimen—an immense relief for all of us. It sounded like a chance to pivot.

    The new chemo was more complex and heavier, but after the very first dose the white count dropped to 60,000—a clear sign the treatment was working. The oncologist, cautiously optimistic, said there was now a real hope of success. Another hope.

    In addition, the doctor suggested adding radiotherapy—daily sessions for 30 days to reinforce the effect of the chemo. I fully supported that decision. There was no other choice anyway.

    I managed to find the necessary funds, and Roxana promptly wired them to the clinic to pay for radiotherapy. Another payment was like a brick in a bridge back to life. Thus, in parallel with chemotherapy, Adam underwent a course of radiation—a new stage in his fight.

chapters.title: 44. “DON’T TELL ADAM”
chapters.html:
Around the same time new reports came from Roxana—about Susannah. She said Susannah had completed a course of chemotherapy, but unbearable abdominal pain had returned. The reason—a large tumor in the intestine. The situation was worsened by the fact that the insurance queue stretched almost a year. Everyone understood: Susannah would not withstand that wait.

    It was a heavy knot, because the suddenly discovered tumor threw everyone off balance.

    Adam knew nothing about it—we deliberately kept him in the dark so as not to shatter an already fragile emotional state.

    Together with Roxana we decided: the tumor had to be removed immediately, in a private clinic. I took on the money again. A friend of mine from my city helped: he gave me a loan quickly and confidently, without extra questions and without a shade of distrust. I had no personal funds left—there were loans too—but we still had a chance to close this gap, because people appeared at exactly the moment they were needed.

    Roxana arranged things with a surgeon she knew—she’s a nurse and by then had weight at work. They managed to organize the operation pro bono, but we had to pay for the operating room and associated costs. Altogether it came to a bearable sum—about $7,000. Yes, more expenses, but I had no doubt: action was needed now.

    Roxana herself couldn’t help with money: she was carrying a substantial loan of roughly $15,000 from prior expenses. Susannah still had part of a loan too—for Adam’s COVID treatment at the end of 2022—and I was paying it down gradually while she underwent therapy.

    Later it turned out Susannah’s tumor was malignant and was growing even against chemo. After removal they prescribed a new course—12 sessions. It was sad news: the previous regimen had hardly worked and had been extremely hard on her.

    Susannah herself had changed beyond recognition. She believed she wouldn’t survive. Even so, she took chemo bravely, without breakdowns, as if silently accepting that the end lay ahead—only more protracted and painful. I refused to accept that. I still believed and wanted to do everything possible to, however hard it was, pull Susannah through. She is part of our family, our team, and I was ready for anything to keep her alive and one day give her a chance to forget all this and live a normal, good life.

chapters.title: 45. BETWEEN DEBTS AND HOPE
chapters.html:
Against the backdrop of all this news, at the end of the year—in December 2024—while Susannah’s situation was worsening, while Adam’s chemo was changed and there was a sharp spike in white cells, and while my debts and loans were piling up, I decided to sell my apartment urgently.

    I had created that apartment entirely myself—I had literally poured my soul into finishing it. But not for a second did I doubt that this step was inevitable and right. Choosing between an apartment and the lives of my friends, I naturally chose them—and their lives.

    The next year, 2025, began just as tensely as the previous ones, though I wanted to break free from the chain of troubles stretching basically from 2019—almost six years. The trials had been especially cruel since 2021, when Adam’s life began collapsing with monstrous speed: severe illness, loss of access to funds, the feeling of utter defenselessness before the system. But the most irreplaceable pain remained the loss of the few who were truly dear to him.

    Adam continued to receive chemotherapy. It was heavy. But still—it worked.

    After several aggressive doses, in the spring, the oncologist suddenly brought unexpectedly encouraging news. He told Adam and Roxana he was confident the treatment would succeed. Moreover, he intensified the final stages of chemo, nearly to the limit, and promised: if Adam endured it—he would be completely free of disease.

    For me it was a true breakthrough, almost a light at the end of the tunnel. Everything seemed real. I immediately began planning our meeting. We discussed the fall—tentatively October—and imagined seeing each other somewhere in Spain or Italy. Given Adam’s legal status and case restrictions, he would need to petition the court for permission to travel outside the U.S. In theory they could grant no more than seven days. That suited us. Because it wasn’t only about the meeting. It was about a symbol. About the chance to gather again—not in fear and not in exhaustion. In a new space, without disease. In a life that—perhaps—was only beginning.

chapters.title: 46. THE GUARANTOR
chapters.html:
But along with rays of hope came a new shadow. One day Roxana sent a short, almost stunning message: Susannah was gone.

    She had died.

    From chemotherapy side effects. She couldn’t withstand them.

    It was a terrible blow. For Roxana, and for me.

    I thought about it every day. For weeks.

    The situation became even harder when it turned out the loan taken in Susannah’s name, under the contract terms, now had to be closed by the guarantor. And the guarantor was Roxana. The amount was huge, and the banks mercilessly froze all her accounts. Even her salary stopped coming in. She wrote to me in a state of genuine apathy.

    I couldn’t leave Roxana in that position. I contacted my friend who had helped me before. And—with gratitude and a slight ache at having to ask again—I requested another loan. He agreed without hesitation. I understood: I would soon sell my apartment and things would become easier.

    In April 2025 the sale closed. I sold that very apartment I had created myself. That had been my pride. My nest. Into which I had put my soul. And I didn’t regret it for a second. Because between an apartment and the people I love—between the material and the human—I choose the latter.

    And now—despite losses, despite pain—we were still drawing closer to the finale. A finale in which Adam would remain alive.

chapters.title: 47. STARTING FROM ZERO
chapters.html:
After Susannah’s death, Roxana finally decided to leave the country. She wrote to me about it: the decision had been ripening in her for a long time.

    Lara, in turn, also made a fateful choice—to move into a home for the elderly where, as she said, there would finally be peace.

    Roxana planned to start from scratch in another country—democratic, respectful of human dignity. I deliberately won’t name the country to preserve confidentiality, but it is a truly decent place. She already had a concrete plan then: she had contacted a clinic that agreed to take her. She only had to finish a few formalities, and she expected to manage it within the next month.

    Roxana leaned on the oncologist’s words, confidently stating that Adam would be cured of Hodgkin lymphoma. Those words became her starting point. For the first time she allowed herself to believe she could breathe differently—freely. She decided she wanted to leave behind all the pain accumulated over years. Everything they had lived through together: death, fear, sleepless nights, breakdowns, despair. Her native country was no longer home. It had become a battlefield where things had taken far too long to end.

    The dogs—Adam’s two and another one Roxana had once rescued as a puppy—remained part of this big family: Adam, Roxana, Susannah, and Lara. They were temporarily handed over, through acquaintances, to a kind young woman who agreed to take them in through the end of 2025.

    I supported Roxana’s decision without hesitation. We both understood: a different chapter was beginning. A chapter where she could live for herself—without the constant presence of pain, fear, and responsibility. We were ready to change the format of our communication. To free her. Perhaps even completely.

chapters.title: 48. A FINISH WITH OBSTACLES
chapters.html:
In June 2025 Adam was due for the last—and heaviest—dose of chemotherapy. The final step in a long and painful road. We believed that it would put a period at the end of this years-long ordeal. But, as had happened before in our story, everything again went off plan.

    The organization that had provided Adam with housing up to that point suddenly withdrew further help. He could no longer stay where he had spent the last months.

    At the same time serious problems arose with paying the clinic—for both the stay during infusion and the medications themselves. The situation was complicated by the fact that Roxana had just moved to a new country where she didn’t yet have established channels of financial support. And all previous payments, including medical ones, had gone through her. The ability to pay simply disappeared.

    As a result of this crisis, Adam ended up in a homeless shelter. They placed him on a cot away from people to minimize the risk of infections.

    I kept the process moving, understanding how crucial that last dose was. If there were a relapse, I would blame myself all my life for not finishing the job, for stopping right at the finish.

    And then, as if by magic, fate intervened.

    At her new workplace, Roxana mentioned Adam’s situation to a colleague—his diagnosis, his being in California, the housing difficulties. The colleague turned out to be compassionate: her relatives lived in Los Angeles and, having learned about Adam, agreed without hesitation to take him in. They set no deadlines or conditions—they simply said they were ready to house him. Roxana, for her part, pledged to cover all food costs.

    This happened literally a day before Adam’s flight to New York—the tickets had already been bought. But after that conversation everything changed. The flight was canceled, and the family of three came to pick him up right at the shelter. He had been in isolation there, alone, in a hard state, but the staff were kind and understanding.

    The family who took him in made a good impression, though he felt strong embarrassment: he feared being a burden.

    Adam moved in with these kind people and began to recuperate, preparing for the final chemotherapy. He behaved extremely quietly and even pretended to be asleep all the time so as not to disturb the family. Meanwhile Roxana organized everything: dates, medications, bookings. Once again she proved to be a brilliant coordinator, managing the crisis at a distance with striking precision.

chapters.title: 49. THE LETTER
chapters.html:
As soon as everything was ready—place, housing, medications—a new problem arrived. That very family hosting Adam received a letter from the bank: their house was to be foreclosed. It turned out they had fallen victim to fraud and couldn’t cover the mortgage arrears. The situation was not merely difficult—it was devastating. They had to vacate urgently, which meant Adam had to find a new place again.

    I began urgently looking for a way out. One idea was to place Adam through a platform like WorkAway—in exchange for helping around the house, so he could stay at least a couple of weeks after chemotherapy. I wrote to dozens of people, but all declined. Adam didn’t like my idea: he was struggling both physically and mentally, and he didn’t want to land in someone’s home.

    In the end Adam made a decision—right after the final dose he would return to New York. As soon as the chemotherapy was over, he discharged himself, got to the airport, and flew. The day was hard, but Adam managed. He remained incredibly strong and determined despite all mobility limitations.

    Side effects began immediately after he returned home, to his apartment in New York. But he was home. And however hard it was, he saw it through to the end. Alone, but unbroken.

    I was genuinely encouraged by how Adam coped. By the fact that he completed the arduous course of treatment and, at the end, returned home on his own—on his own feet. I was encouraged by how he had endured everything. And by how the oncologist promised complete remission. In that moment I allowed myself to believe in the good. Something long-forgotten returned to me—lightness, hope.

    I had even bought tickets to Italy for early October. We began planning our meeting. It seemed the worst was behind us.

    Yes, there was anxiety and uncertainty—after all, Adam had just finished heavy therapy. But despite everything, I held onto that inner light.

    It didn’t last long. Only a couple of weeks. Until the end of June.

chapters.title: 50. I STILL SEE A CHANCE
chapters.html:
At the end of June Roxana sent me a message: Adam’s blood had been drawn for a control test. The results were troubling—the white count had jumped to 35,000.

    It sounded like a bolt from the blue. How? Why so fast? What had gone wrong? The oncologist had said remission had been achieved.

    That moment was a genuine blow. And yet I didn’t let myself break. I acted right away. I began to analyze: what the reason was, what it meant, what options existed. I reviewed Adam’s medical history, gathered data, asked Roxana to contact the doctor and get more information. I had a suspicion: perhaps it was leukemia again. The very one that had once been suppressed by CAR‑T therapy. But perhaps it had returned. Quietly, by stealth.

    At first the lab techs didn’t find blast cells. Only the high white count. Some even suggested it was a post-treatment reaction—a compensatory wave. That it was temporary. That everything would normalize. I hoped it would. That it was a chronic form, something that could be stabilized with tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

    But just five days later a repeat test showed otherwise: the white count was 67,000. And this time leukemic cells were found in the blood. Not of the myeloid type, but lymphoid. They also detected the Philadelphia chromosome. That pointed to chronic lymphocytic leukemia, but the course was atypically fast and aggressive—closer to an acute form. And that was frightening.

    The same oncologist who had treated Adam from the start recommended beginning with a new form of chemotherapy—oral. And after stabilization—to move to tyrosine kinase inhibitors, in particular ponatinib. It was a second heavy blow in a very short time.

    Roxana was crushed. I remember her writing to me: “Nico, we can’t anymore. He can’t. I can’t. And you can’t.”

    But I replied that I still saw a chance. And that I intended to use it.

chapters.title: 51. REAL—UNREAL
chapters.html:
As before, Adam met the new treatment with sharp rejection. He refused at once. He said: “Enough. I will not be treated anymore.” He spoke with the oncologist. Heard the plan. And rejected it. He was resolute. Categorical. And broken.

    But Roxana and I—behind his back, saying nothing—decided we had a right to one more attempt. We arranged this therapy. We organized the delivery. The scheme—14 doses. Chemotherapy—in liquid form.

    And on one of the most symbolic days—on my birthday, on Barbara’s birthday, on the day of the preliminary court hearing—the oncologist handed Adam the packages with the medication.

    On that very day. So it all coincided.

    Then I thought again: yes, this is our story. Real. Unreal. The Real Unreal Story.

chapters.title: 52. EPILOGUE: THE END ISN’T WRITTEN YET
chapters.html:
We are now on a new branch of our tangled, spiraling story—one hard to believe, yet, strangely, absolutely real. And at this moment I am again not ready to give up. But I also clearly understand: we cannot cope alone.

    The oncologist proposed a plan: fourteen courses of chemotherapy and, possibly, repeated radiotherapy to rule out a relapse of Hodgkin’s. But, knowing the path we have already traveled, I understand: things may again go off plan. It could lead to another stem cell transplant—a standard practice in complex forms of leukemia. We also must provide Adam with tyrosine kinase inhibitors if we manage to stabilize the leukemic process and reduce it to a minimum—or, better, eliminate it completely.

    The situation became even more complicated: against the backdrop of the new turn of illness—Adam’s diagnosed leukemia, presumably a mixed form, possibly with residual manifestations of Hodgkin’s—I learned that Roxana was diagnosed with lupus, although she told neither me nor Adam. She—our anchor person, the restraining force and heart of the remaining team—now needed protection herself.

    My financial resources are exhausted. I am physically far away and cannot be with Adam. And still—I won’t give up.

    I told this story—the Real Unreal Story—so that it would not dissolve into oblivion. Because it is real, because it matters. Because I don’t want all this to be left without meaning—as if nothing had happened, as if everything we lived through didn’t deserve memory, understanding, or a chance to be resolved.

    I told it so that it would live—among you. So that, perhaps, someone whose heart it touches could become part of it. Help can take any form—action, information, participation, even simply attention.

    If anything in this story has moved you—don’t walk past.

    I still believe this story can end differently for Adam. For us. Even modestly, but with the right to life and hope. I believe the finale of The Real Unreal Story isn’t written yet.
